posts.name: Alperen Atikebaş
posts.cooked: Hi everyone. We're planning to build a test chassis during the off-season to improve ourselves. Unlike our competition robots, this one won't have any systems installed. It will include a belly pan, something we’re attempting for the first time. However, our technical understanding in this area is limited. We’d appreciate your feedback regarding robot CAD, particularly on how to properly locate the battery cable connector. Specifically, we're unsure how to route the battery cables to the main breaker and PDH (Power Distribution Hub). Below, I've included a link to the OnShape CAD document for reference. Any insights or guidance you can provide would be invaluable.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
n what we did last year...we did a test mule (Milk Crate) of the base as well. It was our first time with swerve. We added everything that would be necessary to operate the base...and only the base. From the looks of your base CAD...you need to add controllers (looks like you are running NEOs), and an IMU. This would be the minimum to run it prior to code. If the Roborio is in the middle...put the IMU on top of it. Running wire to the PDH and the Breaker should be easy on where you have it currently. ``` Alright, so I've got this message here that needs cleaning up. Let me read through it carefully. Okay, the user wants me to remove all HTML tags and any unnecessary elements. That means stripping out things like `

` tags and any span or template tags. Also, I need to ensure the text flows naturally in standard English, preserving the original meaning. They mentioned keeping it as a single paragraph without line breaks, so I'll need to combine those separate paragraphs into one. Hmm, looking at the first part: "Based on what we did last year…we did a test mule (Milk Crate) of the base as well." There's some ellipsis there which isn't standard, maybe replace that with a period or just keep it if it's intended for emphasis. But since they want standard punctuation, probably a period. Then "It was our first time with swerve." Swerve seems like a brand or specific product, so it's fine to leave it as is. Next sentence: "We added everything that would be necessary to operate the base…and only the base." Again, the ellipsis can be changed to a period. "From the looks of your base CAD…you need to add controllers..." Another ellipsis, same approach. I should also check if "you're running NEOs" should be "you are running NEOs" for proper grammar. Wait, in the original, it says "you are running NEOs", so actually, that's correct. Maybe that part is okay. The part about the Roborio: "IF the Roborio is in the middle…put the IMU on top of it." IF should be capitalized as it's the start of a sentence, but considering context, maybe not? Hmm, depends on how formal it needs to be. Since the user wants minimal changes, perhaps leave it as is unless it's incorrect. Actually, in proper English, "if" should be lowercase unless it's the beginning of a sentence. So maybe capitalize it. Lastly, "Running wire to the PDH and the Breaker should be easy on where you have it currently." PDH is likely an abbreviation, so that's fine. "should be easy on" – does that make sense? Should it be "should be straightforward"? Maybe, but the user wants minimal changes. So perhaps just leave it as is unless it's grammatically wrong. Putting it all together, ensuring all HTML tags are removed, combining the paragraphs, adjusting punctuation, and capitalizing appropriately. Make sure it's a single coherent paragraph without line breaks. Alright, I think that covers the main points. Time to write the cleaned-up version. ``` **Step-by-Step Explanation:** 1. **Remove HTML Tags:** Eliminate `

` tags and any other non-standard markup to ensure plain text formatting. 2. **Combine Paragraphs:** Merge the separated paragraphs into a single block to maintain a fluid reading flow. 3. **Adjust Punctuation:** Replace ellipses (`…`) with periods (`.`) to adhere to standard English punctuation rules. 4. **Correct Grammar:** Ensure proper capitalization, such as capitalizing "If" at the start of a sentence. 5. **Preserve Meaning:** Maintain technical terms and specific details ("swerve," "PDH," etc.) as they hold crucial information. 6. **Final Formatting:** Ensure the text is concise, grammatically correct, and free of unnecessary elements while retaining its original intent. By following these steps, the cleaned-up text will be clear, professional, and maintain the integrity of the original message. ```

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: And after looking at the belly pan a bit more, the arcs at the corners could be a bit closer to the wheels. Your base is about 27x27 inches, and you may need more real estate for other items in the future. It is always good to plan for that. Additionally, another thing to consider is watching this video. I am not saying your design is bad—it is actually very good. This would help you as you go into the swerve.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Alperen Atikebaş
posts.cooked:
First of all, thank you for your answer. Yes, we use NEO V1.1 brushless motors in our robot and a Spark Max motor controller. Additionally, we employ a functional 3D-printed bracket to secure the Spark Maxes and minimize cable clutter. Below is a photo illustrating this setup.

We also utilize NavX2 as our IMU. As previously noted, Roborio serves as the central component, with the IMU mounted on it.

In terms of the Belly Pan surface area, we find that the current configuration provides adequate space without the need for additional modifications. This chassis functions primarily as a testing platform for software development and ensuring robot stability, without supporting extra systems.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: It depends on what you're after here... But I'd recommend keeping it solid so that you have a heavier chassis, which will be more representative of an actual robot for programmers and drivers, but less good experience for making a belly pan for your build crew. Just a thought! You could also add weights!

Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version:

"I’d suggest discarding the frame, similar to many 2024 robotic models, including this one."

Let me know if you'd like further adjustments!

Here’s how I’d clean up the text: --- From a purely programming viewpoint, I would suggest adding a vision system if possible. Running vision localization on our test chassis was a significant advantage this offseason. --- Changes made: - Removed `

` tags. - Simplified "some sort of" to "a". - Changed "a huge blessing" to "a significant advantage" for better clarity and conciseness. - Ensured proper grammar and punctuation. - Kept everything in a single, flowing paragraph without line breaks. The main goal is to preserve the original meaning while improving readability and ensuring proper English usage.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
In terms of frame size, one thing you might want to consider is setting your frame size before the season starts. We did that for the first time this year and it significantly accelerated our early robot progress. We set our size to 27.5 inches by 27.5 inches, and that worked well for us this year. However, depending on your robot architecture, that might not always be feasible—for example, if you're working with something like a 359 requiring a longer robot for the pink arm.  

The main benefit of doing this is that you can start assembling and wiring your robot chassis before the design is finalized. The same applies to bumper construction.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Tanmay Darji
posts.cooked: For the belly pan, I would recommend doing something like a pegboard with holes at a standard distance and some tap size. Our current chassis has 10-32 tap holes every inch, which can be used for future mounting if needed.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: An 0.201” hole can be a 10-32 clearance or a 1/4-20 tap hole.
